dt: {bc}to run away secretly with the intention of getting married usually without parental consent

dt.t: … Waterman was a peevish child who grew into a defiant teenager, {wi}eloped{/wi} at 18 largely to shock his father, and then—far too young—was a father himself.

dt: {bc}to run away from one's spouse with a lover

dt.t: " … when they had been married nearly seven years, and were within a few weeks of the time when the brother's death would have adjusted all, she {wi}eloped{/wi} with a younger man, and left him."
… might have mistaken him for … some scarecrow {it}eloped{/it} from a cornfield.

dt: {bc}to leave a health-care or educational facility without permission or authorization

dt.t: …10 suicidal patients deemed {lsquo}high risk for suicide{rsquo} {wi}eloped{/wi} from the Emergency Department from October 2014 and February 2015.
Police in Ohio said this week that they gave a nursing home resident a ride and dropped him off at a gas station without ever knowing he was a dementia patient who had {wi}eloped{/wi}.

utxt.t: … the young couple at a nearby table sent over some of their dessert, a slice of cake specially ordered to celebrate their {wi}elopement{/wi}.

… if the child is afraid of loud noises or crowded environments, a classroom could be intimidating and cause him to be anxious. He might engage in problematic behaviors such as {wi}elopement{/wi} (running away), hand flapping, or yelling …

And of course, Las Vegas is no longer just for {wi}elopers{/wi}. With all the elegant hotels springing up in Sin City, more couples are choosing to haul the whole wedding party out and do things up right.

et: Anglo-French {it}aloper, esloper{/it} to abduct, run away
shortdef: to run away secretly with the intention of getting married usually without parental consent
to run away from one's spouse with a lover
